info.title: Explore education statistics - Public Data API

get.description: Gets a data set's summary details.

parameters.name: dataSetId
parameters.description: The ID of the data set.

get.description: Get the metadata about a data set. Use this to create data set queries.

parameters.name: types
parameters.description:
The types of meta to get for the requested data set version.

Can be any combination of the following:

- `Filters` - include all meta relating to *filters*
- `Indicators` - include all meta relating to *indicators*
- `Locations` - include all meta relating to *locations*
- `TimePeriods` - include all meta relating to *time periods*

schema.description:
The types of meta to get for the requested data set version.

Can be any combination of the following:

- `Filters` - include all meta relating to *filters*
- `Indicators` - include all meta relating to *indicators*
- `Locations` - include all meta relating to *locations*
- `TimePeriods` - include all meta relating to *time periods*

parameters.name: dataSetVersion
parameters.description:
The data set version e.g. 1.0, 1.1, 2.0, etc.
Wildcard versions are supported. For example, `2.*` returns the latest minor version in the v2 series.

parameters.name: dataSetId
parameters.description: The ID of the data set.

200.description: The requested data set version metadata.

get.description:
Query a data set using a `GET` request, returning the filtered results.
            
Note that there is a `POST` variant of this endpoint which provides a more complete set
of querying functionality. The `GET` variant is only recommended for initial exploratory
testing or simple queries that do not need advanced functionality.
            
Unlike the `POST` variant, this endpoint does not allow condition clauses (`and`, `or`, `not`)
and consequently cannot express more complex queries. Use the `POST` variant instead for these
types of queries.
            
## Indicators
            
The `indicators` query parameter is used to include only specific values in the data set
results.
            
Each indicator should be a string containing the indicator ID e.g. `4xbOu`, `8g1RI`.
            
Omitting the `indicators` parameter will return values for all indicators.

## Filters
            
The `filters` query parameter is used to filter by other filter options (not locations,
geographic levels or time periods).
            
Each filter should be a string containing the required filter option ID e.g. `z4FQE`, `DcQeg`.
            
## Geographic levels
            
The `geographicLevels` query parameter is used to filter results by geographic level.
            
The geographic levels are specified as codes, and can be one of the following:
            
- `EDA` - English devolved area
- `INST` - Institution
- `LA` - Local authority
- `LAD` - Local authority district
- `LEP` - Local enterprise partnership
- `LSIP` - Local skills improvement plan area
- `MCA` - Mayoral combined authority
- `MAT` - MAT
- `NAT` - National
- `OA` - Opportunity area
- `PA` - Planning area
- `PCON` - Parliamentary constituency
- `PROV` - Provider
- `REG` - Regional
- `RSC` - RSC region
- `SCH` - School
- `SPON` - Sponsor
- `WARD` - Ward
            
## Locations
            
The `locations` query parameter is used to filter results by location.
            
The locations should be strings formatted like `{level}|{property}|{value}` where:
            
- `{level}` is the location's level code (e.g. `NAT`, `REG`, `LA`)
- `{property}` is the name of the identifying property to match on (e.g. `id, `code`, `urn`)
- `{value}` is the value for the property to match
            
An ID or a code can be used to identify a location, with the following differences:
            
- IDs only match a **single location**
- Codes may match **multiple locations**
            
Whilst codes are generally unique to a single location, they can be used for multiple locations.
This may match more results than you expect so it's recommended to use IDs where possible.
            
### Examples
            
- `LA|code|E08000019` matches any local authority with code `E08000019`
- `REG|id|6bQgZ` matches any region with ID `6bQgZ`
- `SCH|urn|140821` matches any school with URN `140821`
            
## Time periods
            
The `timePeriods` query parameter is used to filter results by time period.
            
The time periods should be strings formatted like `{period}|{code}` where:
            
- `period` is the time period or range (e.g. `2020` or `2020/2021`)
- `code` is the code identifying the time period type (e.g. `AY`, `CY`, `M1`, `W20`)
            
The `period` should be a single year like `2020`, or a range like `2020/2021`.
Currently, only years (or year ranges) are supported.
            
Some time period types span two years e.g. financial year part 2 (`P2`), or may fall in a
latter year e.g. academic year summer term (`T3`). For these types, a singular year `period`
like `2020` is considered as `2020/2021`.
            
For example, a `period` value of `2020` is applicable to the following time periods:
            
- 2020 calendar year
- 2020/2021 academic year
- 2020/2021 financial year part 2 (October to March)
- 2020/2021 academic year's summer term
            
If you wish to be more explicit, you may use a range for the `period` e.g. `2020/2021`.
However, a range cannot be used with time period types which only span a single year,
for example, `2020/21` cannot be used with `CY`, `M` or `W` codes.
            
### Examples
            
- `2020|AY` is the 2020/21 academic year
- `2021|FY` is the 2021/22 financial year
- `2020|T3` is the 2020/21 academic year's summer term
- `2020|P2` is the 2020/21 financial year part 2 (October to March)
- `2020|CY` is the 2020 calendar year
- `2020|W32` is 2020 week 32
- `2020/2021|AY` is the 2020/21 academic year
- `2021/2022|FY` is the 2021/22 financial year
            
## Sorts
            
The `sorts` query parameter is used to sort the results.
            
Sorts are applied in the order they are provided and should be strings
formatted like `{field}|{direction}` where:
            
- `field` is the name of the field to sort e.g. `timePeriod`
- `direction` is the direction to sort in e.g. ascending (`Asc`) or descending (`Desc`)
            
The `field` can be one of the following:
            
- `timePeriod` to sort by time period
- `geographicLevel` to sort by the geographic level of the data
- `location|{level}` to sort by locations in a geographic level where `{level}` is the level code (e.g. `REG`, `LA`)
- `filter|{id}` to sort by the options in a filter where `{id}` is the filter ID (e.g. `3RxWP`)
- `indicator|{id}` to sort by the values in a indicator where `{id}` is the indicator ID (e.g. `6VfPgZ`)
            
### Examples
            
- `timePeriod|Desc` sorts by time period in descending order
- `geographicLevel|Asc` sorts by geographic level in ascending order
- `location|REG|Asc` sorts by regions in ascending order
- `filter|3RxWP|Desc` sorts by options in filter `3RxWP` in descending order
- `indicator|7a1dk|Asc` sorts by values in indicator `7a1dk` in ascending order

parameters.name: dataSetId
parameters.description: The ID of the data set.

parameters.name: dataSetVersion
parameters.description:
The data set version e.g. 1.0, 1.1, 2.0, etc.
Wildcard versions are supported. For example, `2.*` returns the latest minor version in the v2 series.

parameters.name: filters.in
parameters.description: Filter the results to have a filter option matching at least one of these IDs.

parameters.name: filters.notIn
parameters.description: Filter the results to not have a filter option matching any of these IDs.

parameters.name: filters.eq
parameters.description: Filter the results to have a filter option matching this ID.

parameters.name: filters.notEq
parameters.description: Filter the results to not have a filter option matching this ID.

parameters.name: geographicLevels.in
parameters.description: Filter the results to be in one of these geographic levels.

parameters.name: geographicLevels.notIn
parameters.description: Filter the results to not be in one of these geographic levels.

parameters.name: geographicLevels.eq
parameters.description: Filter the results to be in this geographic level.

parameters.name: geographicLevels.notEq
parameters.description: Filter the results to not be in this geographic level.

parameters.name: locations.eq
parameters.description: Filter the results to be in this location.

parameters.name: locations.notEq
parameters.description: Filter the results to not be in this location.

parameters.name: locations.in
parameters.description: Filter the results to be in one of these locations.

parameters.name: locations.notIn
parameters.description: Filter the results not to be in one of these locations.

parameters.name: timePeriods.eq
parameters.description: Filter the results to be in this time period.

parameters.name: timePeriods.notEq
parameters.description: Filter the results to not be in this time period.

parameters.name: timePeriods.in
parameters.description: Filter the results to be in one of these time periods.

parameters.name: timePeriods.notIn
parameters.description: Filter the results to not be in one of these time periods.

parameters.name: timePeriods.gt
parameters.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically greater than the one specified.

parameters.name: timePeriods.gte
parameters.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically greater than or equal to the one specified.

parameters.name: timePeriods.lt
parameters.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically less than the one specified.

parameters.name: timePeriods.lte
parameters.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically less than or equal to the one specified.

parameters.name: indicators
parameters.description:
The IDs of indicators to return values for.

Omitting this parameter will return values for all indicators.

schema.description:
The IDs of indicators to return values for.

Omitting this parameter will return values for all indicators.

parameters.name: sorts
parameters.description:
The sorts to apply to the results. Sorts at the start of the
list will be applied first.
            
By default, results are sorted by time period in descending order.

schema.description:
The sorts to apply to the results. Sorts at the start of the
list will be applied first.
            
By default, results are sorted by time period in descending order.

parameters.name: debug
parameters.description:
Enable debug mode. Results will be formatted with human-readable
labels to assist in identification.
            
This **should not** be enabled in a production environment.

schema.description:
Enable debug mode. Results will be formatted with human-readable
labels to assist in identification.
            
This **should not** be enabled in a production environment.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page of results to fetch.

schema.description: The page of results to fetch.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description: The maximum number of results per page.

schema.description: The maximum number of results per page.

200.description: The paginated list of query results.

post.description:
Query a data set using a `POST` request, returning the filtered results.
            
Note that for simpler queries or exploratory testing, there is also GET variant of this endpoint
only handles a smaller subset of querying functionality. However, for most use-cases,
this endpoint is recommended as it provides the complete set of functionality.
            
Unlike the `GET` endpoint, the `POST` endpoint allows condition criteria (`and`, `or`, `not`)
and consequently can express more complex queries.
            
A `POST` request without a body will return a paginated set of unfiltered results and will include
values for all indicators.
            
A `Content-Type` request header of `application/json` is required.

parameters.name: dataSetId
parameters.description: The ID of the data set.

parameters.name: dataSetVersion
parameters.description:
The data set version e.g. 1.0, 1.1, 2.0, etc.
Wildcard versions are supported. For example, `2.*` returns the latest minor version in the v2 series.

schema.description: A data set query to match results against.

200.description: The paginated list of query results.

get.summary: Download a data set as CSV
get.description:
The CSV response will render its metadata in a human-readable format (instead of
machine-readable IDs). The CSV is not subject to the same backward compatibility
guarantees as the data set's JSON representation in other endpoints.

get.summary: Get a data set version's changes

The data set version e.g. 1.0, 1.1, 2.0, etc.
Wildcard versions are supported. For example, `2.*` returns the latest minor version in the v2 series.

parameters.description: Whether to include change logs for all associated patches will be in the results.

200.description: The changes for the data set version.

filters.description: A list of any filter changes made to the data set.

filterOptions.description: A list of any filter option changes made to the data set.

geographicLevels.description: A list of any geographic level changes made to the data set.

locationGroups.description: A list of any location group changes made to the data set.

locationOptions.description: A list of any location option changes made to the data set.

timePeriods.description: A list of any time period changes made to the data set.

ChangeSetViewModel.description: A set of changes grouped by their type (major or minor).

eq.description: Filter the results to have a filter option matching this ID.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not have a filter option matching this ID.

in.description: Filter the results to have a filter option matching at least one of these IDs.

notIn.description: Filter the results to not have a filter option matching any of these IDs.

DataSetGetQueryFilters.description: The filter option criteria to filter results by in a data set GET query.

eq.description: Filter the results to be in this geographic level.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not be in this geographic level.

in.description: Filter the results to be in one of these geographic levels.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not be in this location.

notIn.description: Filter the results not to be in one of these locations.

DataSetGetQueryLocations.description:
The location option criteria to filter results by in a data set GET query.
            
The results can be matched by either the location option's ID or a code.
Note the following differences:
            
- IDs only match a **single location**
- Codes may match **multiple locations**
            
Whilst codes are generally unique to a single location, they can be
used for multiple locations. This may match more results than you
expect so it's recommended to use IDs where possible.

filters.description: Query criteria relating to filter options.

geographicLevels.description: Query criteria relating to geographic levels.

locations.description: Query criteria relating to location options.

timePeriods.description: Query criteria relating to time periods.

indicators.description:
The IDs of indicators to return values for.

Omitting this parameter will return values for all indicators.

sorts.description:
The sorts to apply to the results. Sorts at the start of the
list will be applied first.
            
By default, results are sorted by time period in descending order.

debug.description:
Enable debug mode. Results will be formatted with human-readable
labels to assist in identification.
            
This **should not** be enabled in a production environment.

page.description: The page of results to fetch.

pageSize.description: The maximum number of results per page.

DataSetGetQueryRequest.description: A data set GET query request.

eq.description: Filter the results to be in this time period.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not be in this time period.

in.description: Filter the results to be in one of these time periods.

notIn.description: Filter the results to not be in one of these time periods.

Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically greater than the one specified.

chronologically greater than or equal to the one specified.

version.description: The version number. Follows semantic versioning e.g. 2.0 (major), 1.1 (minor).

totalResults.description: The total number of results available to query in the data set.

file.description: The file that this data set version is based on.

timePeriods.description: The time period range covered by the data set.

geographicLevels.description: The geographic levels available in the data set.

filters.description: The filters available in the data set.

indicators.description: The indicators available in the data set.

DataSetLatestVersionViewModel.description: Provides high-level information about the latest version of a data set.

page.description: The page of results to fetch.

pageSize.description: The maximum number of results per page.

types.description:
The types of meta to get for the requested data set version.

Can be any combination of the following:

- `Filters` - include all meta relating to *filters*
- `Indicators` - include all meta relating to *indicators*
- `Locations` - include all meta relating to *locations*
- `TimePeriods` - include all meta relating to *time periods*

filters.description: All the filters associated with the data set.

indicators.description: All the indicators associated with the data set.

geographicLevels.description: All the geographic levels associated with the data set.

locations.description: All the locations associated with the data set, grouped by geographic level.

timePeriods.description: All the time periods associated with the data set.

DataSetMetaViewModel.description: All the metadata associated with a data set.

paging.description: Provides metadata for use in pagination.

results.description: The list of results for this page.

DataSetPaginatedListViewModel.description: A paginated list of data sets.

and.description: The sub-criteria which all must resolve to true.

DataSetQueryCriteriaAnd.description:
A condition criteria where one or more sub-criteria must all resolve
to true for the overall query to match any results.
            
This is equivalent to the `AND` operator in SQL.

filters.description: Query criteria relating to filter options.

geographicLevels.description: Query criteria relating to geographic levels.

locations.description: Query criteria relating to location options.

timePeriods.description: Query criteria relating to time periods.

DataSetQueryCriteriaFacets.description:
A set of criteria specifying which facets the query should match results with.
            
All parts of the criteria must resolve to true to match a result.

eq.description: Filter the results to have a filter option matching this ID.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not have a filter option matching this ID.

in.description: Filter the results to have a filter option matching at least one of these IDs.

notIn.description: Filter the results to not have a filter option matching any of these IDs.

DataSetQueryCriteriaFilters.description: The filter option criteria to filter results by in a data set query.

eq.description: Filter the results to be in this geographic level.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not be in this geographic level.

in.description: Filter the results to be in one of these geographic levels.

notIn.description: Filter the results to not be in one of these geographic levels.

DataSetQueryCriteriaGeographicLevels.description: The geographic levels criteria to filter results by in a data set query.

eq.description: Filter the results to be in this location.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not be in this location.

in.description: Filter the results to be in one of these locations.

notIn.description: Filter the results to not be in one of these locations.

DataSetQueryCriteriaLocations.description:
The location option criteria to filter results by in a data set query.
            
The results can be matched by either the location option's ID or a code.
Note the following differences:
            
- IDs only match a **single location**
- Codes may match **multiple locations**
            
Whilst codes are generally unique to a single location, they can be
used for multiple locations. This may match more results than you
expect so it's recommended to use IDs where possible.

not.description: The sub-criteria which must resolve to false.

DataSetQueryCriteriaNot.description:
A condition criteria where its sub-criteria must resolve
to *false* for the overall query to match any results.
            
This is equivalent to the `NOT` operator in SQL.

or.description: The sub-criteria where one must resolve to true.

DataSetQueryCriteriaOr.description:
A condition criteria where at least one sub-criteria must resolve
to true for the overall query to match any results.
            
This is equivalent to the `OR` operator in SQL.

eq.description: Filter the results to be in this time period.

notEq.description: Filter the results to not be in this time period.

in.description: Filter the results to be in one of these time periods.

notIn.description: Filter the results to not be in one of these time periods.

gt.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically greater than the one specified.

gte.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically greater than or equal to the one specified.

lt.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically less than the one specified.

lte.description:
Filter the results to be in a time period that is
chronologically less than or equal to the one specified.

DataSetQueryCriteriaTimePeriods.description: The time period criteria to filter results by in a data set query.

code.description:
The code of the location. This may be an ONS code, or some
other code that identifies the location.

level.description:
The geographic level of the location.
            
This should be a valid geographic level code e.g. `NAT`, `REG`, `LA`.

DataSetQueryLocationCode.description:
A location (identified by a code) to filter results by.
            
Note that location codes may correspond to multiple locations in the same geographic level.

id.description:
The ID of the location. If specified, this will be used
instead of any codes or other types of identifier.

level.description:
The geographic level of the location.
            
This should be a valid geographic level code e.g. `NAT`, `REG`, `LA`.

DataSetQueryLocationId.description:
A location (identified by an ID) to filter results by.
            
Note that location IDs are guaranteed to be unique to a single location
unlike location codes (which may correspond to multiple locations).

code.description:
The ONS code of the local authority. This is typically 9 characters
in the standard ONS format for local authorities e.g. `E08000019`,
but may be a combination of multiple codes e.g. `E08000019 / E08000020`.

level.description: The geographic level of the local authority. Must be set to `LA`.

DataSetQueryLocationLocalAuthorityCode.description: A local authority (identified by its ONS code) to filter results by.

oldCode.description:
The old code (previously the LEA code) of the local authority.
This is typically a 3-digit number e.g. `318`, but may be a
combination of multiple codes e.g. `318 / 319`.

level.description: The geographic level of the local authority. Must be set to `LA`.

DataSetQueryLocationLocalAuthorityOldCod.description: A local authority (identified by its old code) to filter results by.

ukprn.description:
The UKPRN (UK provider reference number) of the provider.
This is typically an 8-digit number.

level.description: The geographic level of the provider. Must be set to `PROV`.

DataSetQueryLocationProviderUkprn.description: A provider (identified by its UKPRN) to filter results by.

laEstab.description:
The LAESTAB (local authority establishment number) of the school.
This is typically a 7-digit number.

level.description: The geographic level of the location. Must be set to `SCH`.

DataSetQueryLocationSchoolLaEstab.description: A school (identified by its LAESTAB) to filter results by.

urn.description:
The URN (unique reference number) of the school.
This is typically a 6-digit number.

level.description: The geographic level of the school. Must be set to `SCH`.

DataSetQueryLocationSchoolUrn.description: A school (identified by its URN) to filter results by.

paging.description: Provides metadata for use in pagination.

results.description: The list of results for this page.

warnings.description: A list of warnings, highlighting any potential issues with the request.

DataSetQueryPaginatedResultsViewModel.description: A paginated list of results from a data set query.

indicators.description:
The IDs of indicators to return values for.

Omitting this parameter will return values for all indicators.

sorts.description:
The sorts to sort the results by. Sorts at the start of the
list will be applied first.
            
By default, results are sorted by time period in descending order.

debug.description:
Enable debug mode. Results will be formatted with human-readable
labels to assist in identification.
            
This **should not** be enabled in a production environment.

page.description: The page of results to fetch.

pageSize.description: The maximum number of results per page.

DataSetQueryRequest.description: A data set query to match results against.

timePeriod.description: The time period relevant to this result's data.

geographicLevel.description: The geographic level relevant to this result's data.

locations.description:
The locations relevant to this result's data.
            
This is a dictionary where the key is the location's geographic
level and the value is the location's ID.

filters.description:
The filters associated with this result.
            
This is a dictionary where the key is the filter ID and
the value is the specific filter option ID.

values.description:
The data values for the result's indicators.
            
This is a dictionary where the key is the indicator ID
and the value is the data value.

DataSetQueryResultViewModel.description: A result from a data set query containing its values and any facets relevant to it.

field.description:
The name of the field to sort by. This can be one of the following:
            
- `timePeriod` to sort by time period
- `geographicLevel` to sort by the geographic level of the data
- `location|{level}` to sort by locations in a geographic level where `{level}` is the level code (e.g. `REG`, `LA`)
- `filter|{id}` to sort by the options in a filter where `{id}` is the filter ID (e.g. `3RxWP`)
- `indicator|{id}` to sort by the values in a indicator where `{id}` is the indicator ID (e.g. `6VfPgZ`)

direction.description:
The direction to sort by. This can be one of the following:
            
- `Asc` - sort by ascending order
- `Desc` - sort by descending order

DataSetQuerySort.description:
Specifies how the results from a data set query should be sorted.
            
This consists of a field in the data set and a direction to sort by.

period.description:
The time period to match results by.
            
This should be a single year like `2020` or a range like `2020/2021`.

code.description:
The code identifying the time period type to match results by.
            
This should be a valid time period code e.g. `AY`, `CY`, `M1`, `W20`.

DataSetQueryTimePeriod.description:
A time period to filter results by.
            
- `period` is the time period or range (e.g. `2020` or `2020/2021`)
- `code` is the code identifying the time period type (e.g. `AY`, `CY`, `M1`, `W20`)
            
The `period` should be a single year like `2020`, or a range like `2020/2021`.
Currently, only years (or year ranges) are supported.
            
Some time period types span two years e.g. financial year part 2 (`P2`), or may fall in a
latter year e.g. academic year summer term (`T3`). For these types, a singular year `period`
like `2020` is considered as `2020/2021`.
            
For example, a `period` value of `2020` is applicable to the following time periods:
            
- 2020 calendar year
- 2020/2021 academic year
- 2020/2021 financial year part 2 (October to March)
- 2020/2021 academic year's summer term
            
If you wish to be more explicit, you may use a range for the `period` e.g. `2020/2021`.
However, a range cannot be used with time period types which only span a single year,
for example, `2020/21` cannot be used with `CY`, `M` or `W` codes.
            
Some examples:
            
- `2020|AY` is the 2020/21 academic year
- `2021|FY` is the 2021/22 financial year
- `2020|T3` is the 2020/21 academic year's summer term
- `2020|P2` is the 2020/21 financial year part 2 (October to March)
- `2020|CY` is the 2020 calendar year
- `2020|W32` is 2020 week 32
- `2020/2021|AY` is the 2020/21 academic year
- `2021/2022|FY` is the 2021/22 financial year

notes.description: Guideline notes that are associated with the data set version.

versionNumber.description: The version number. Follows semantic versioning e.g. 2.0 (major), 1.1 (minor), 2.1.1 (patch).

majorChanges.description: Any major changes that were made to the data set.

minorChanges.description: Any minor changes that were made to the data set.

DataSetVersionChangeSet.description: A set of changes made to a data set version.

notes.description: Guideline notes that are associated with the data set version.

versionNumber.description: The version number. Follows semantic versioning e.g. 2.0 (major), 1.1 (minor), 2.1.1 (patch).

majorChanges.description: Any major changes that were made to the data set.

minorChanges.description: Any minor changes that were made to the data set.

patchHistory.description: Change logs for any patch versions associated with this change log

DataSetVersionChangesViewModel.description: A set of changes made to a data set version that can optionally include any patch change sets associated with the data set version if it has patch version history.

DataSetVersionFileViewModel.description: Details about the file a data set version is based on.

page.description: The page of results to fetch.

pageSize.description: The maximum number of results per page.

paging.description: Provides metadata for use in pagination.

results.description: The list of results for this page.

DataSetVersionPaginatedListViewModel.description: A paginated list of data set versions.

DataSetVersionReleaseViewModel.description: Details about the statistical release a data set version was published with.

version.description: The version number. Follows semantic versioning e.g. 2.0 (major), 1.1 (minor), 2.1.1 (patch).

type.description:
The version type. Can be one of the following:
            
- `Major` - backwards incompatible changes are being introduced
- `Minor` - backwards compatible changes are being introduced
            
Major versions typically indicate that some action may be required
to ensure code that consumes the data set continues to work.
            
Minor versions should not cause issues in the functionality of existing code.

status.description:
The versions status. Can be one of the following:
            
- `Published` - the version is published and can be used
- `Deprecated` - the version is being deprecated and will not be usable in the future
- `Withdrawn` - the version has been withdrawn and can no longer be used

notes.description: Any notes about this version and its changes.

totalResults.description: The total number of results available to query in the data set.

file.description: The file that this data set version is based on.

release.description: The statistical release that this version was published with.

timePeriods.description: The time period range covered by the data set.

geographicLevels.description: The geographic levels available in the data set.

filters.description: The filters available in the data set.

indicators.description: The indicators available in the data set.

DataSetVersionViewModel.description: Provides high-level information about a data set version.

id.description: The ID of the data set.

title.description: The title of the data set.

summary.description: A summary of the data sets contents.
summary.example: Absence information for all enrolments in schools.

status.description:
The status of the data set. Can be one of the following:
            
- `Published` - the data set has been published and will receive updates
- `Deprecated` - the data set is being discontinued and will no longer receive updates
- `Withdrawn` - the data set has been withdrawn and can no longer be used

supersedingDataSetId.description: The ID of the data set that supersedes this data set (if it has been deprecated).

latestVersion.description: The latest published data set version.

DataSetViewModel.description: Provides high-level information about a data set.

path.description:
The path to the property on the request that the error relates to.
May be omitted or empty if no specific property of the
request relates to the error (it is a 'global' error).

code.description:
The error's machine-readable code. Can be used for further
processing of the error before presenting to users.
May be omitted if there is none.

detail.description:
Additional detail about the error that can be used to provide
more context to users. May be omitted if there is none.

ErrorViewModel.description:
Describes an error that occurred with the request. This will typically
need to be rectified before the request can be fully processed.

currentState.description:
The current state after the change was made.
If the change is an addition, this will be null.

previousState.description:
The previous state before the change was made.
If the change is a deletion, this will be null.

options.description: The filter options belonging to this filter.

hint.description: A hint to assist in describing the filter.

currentState.description:
The current state after the change was made.
If the change is an addition, this will be null.

GeographicLevelChangeViewModel.description: A change to a geographic level option in a data set.

GeographicLevelCode.description:
The code for a geographic level that locations are grouped by.

The allowed values are:

- `EDA` - English devolved area
- `INST` - Institution
- `LA` - Local authority
- `LAD` - Local authority district
- `LEP` - Local enterprise partnership
- `LSIP` - Local skills improvement plan area
- `MCA` - Mayoral combined authority
- `MAT` - MAT
- `NAT` - National
- `OA` - Opportunity area
- `PA` - Planning area
- `PCON` - Parliamentary constituency
- `PROV` - Provider
- `REG` - Regional
- `RSC` - RSC region
- `SCH` - School
- `SPON` - Sponsor
- `WARD` - Ward

code.description: The code for the geographic level.

label.description: The human-readable label for the geographic level.

GeographicLevelViewModel.description: A geographic level (e.g. national, regional) covered by a data set.

currentState.description:
The current state after the change was made.
If the change is an addition, this will be null.

previousState.description:
The previous state before the change was made.
If the change is a deletion, this will be null.

IndicatorChangeViewModel.description: A change to an indicator in a data set.

IndicatorUnit.description:
The recommended unit to format an indicator with.

The allowed values are:

- `""` - No units with numeric formatting where possible e.g. `123,500,600`
- `` - Pound sterling with numeric formatting e.g. `1,234,500`
- `m` - Pound sterling in millions with numeric formatting e.g. `1,234m`
- `%` - Percentage with numeric formatting e.g. `1,234.56%`
- `pp` - Percentage points with numeric formatting e.g. `1,234pp`
- `string` - String with no units and no numeric formatting e.g. `123500600`

column.description: The name of the indicator CSV column.

label.description: The human-readable label of the indicator.

unit.description: The type of unit that should be used when formatting the indicator.

decimalPlaces.description: The recommended number of decimal places to use when formatting the indicator.

IndicatorViewModel.description: A type of data point measured by a data set.

pageSize.description: The maximum number of results per page.

totalResults.description: The total number of results across all pages.

type.description:
A URI reference (RFC3986) that identifies the problem type. It should
provide human-readable documentation for the problem type.

title.description: A short, human-readable summary of the problem type.
title.example: One or more validation errors occurred.

status.description: The HTTP status code generated by the origin server for the problem.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to the problem.

instance.description:
A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem.
It may or may not yield further information about the problem.

ProblemDetailsViewModel.description:
Describes a problem that occurred whilst processing the request.
The format is based on RFC7807.

search.description: A search term to find matching publications.

page.description: The page of results to fetch.

pageSize.description: The maximum number of results per page.

paging.description: Provides metadata for use in pagination.

results.description: The list of results for this page.

PublicationPaginatedListViewModel.description: A paginated list of publication summaries.

title.example: Pupil absence in schools in England

slug.description: The URL slug of the publication.

lastPublished.description: When the publication was last published.

PublicationSummaryViewModel.description: Provides summary information about a publication.

TimePeriodCode.description:
The code identifying the time period's type.

The allowed values are:

- `AY` - academic year
- `AYQ1 - AYQ4` - academic year quarter 1 to 4
- `T1` - academic year's autumn term
- `T2` - academic year's spring term
- `T3` - academic year's summer term
- `T1T2` - academic year's autumn and spring term
- `CY` - calendar year
- `CYQ1 - CYQ4` - calendar year quarter 1 to 4
- `RY` - reporting year
- `P1` - financial year part 1 (April to September)
- `P2` - financial year part 2 (October to March)
- `FY` - financial year
- `FYQ1 - FYQ4` - financial year quarter 1 to 4
- `TY` - tax year
- `TYQ1 - FYQ4` - tax year quarter 1 to 4
- `W1 - W52` - week 1 to 52
- `M1 - M12` - month 1 to 12

currentState.description:
The current state after the change was made.
If the change is an addition, this will be null.

previousState.description:
The previous state before the change was made.
If the change is a deletion, this will be null.

end.description: The ending time period in human-readable format.

period.description: The period covered by the data e.g. '2020' or '2020/2021'.

type.description:
A URI reference (RFC3986) that identifies the problem type. It should
provide human-readable documentation for the problem type.

title.description: A short, human-readable summary of the problem type.
title.example: One or more validation errors occurred.

detail.description: A human-readable explanation specific to the problem.

instance.description:
A URI reference that identifies the specific occurrence of the problem.
It may or may not yield further information about the problem.

status.description: The HTTP status code generated by the origin server for the problem.

errors.description: The errors relating to the validation problem.

ValidationProblemViewModel.description:
A validation problem that has occurred with the API request.
This type of response will be composed of one or more errors
relating to the request and its properties.

path.description:
The path to the property on the request that the warning relates to.
May be omitted or be empty if no specific property of the
request relates to the warning (it is a 'global' warning).

code.description:
The warning's machine-readable code. Can be used for further
processing of the warning before presenting to users.

detail.description:
Additional detail about the warning that can be used to provide
more context to users. May be omitted if there is none.

WarningViewModel.description:
A warning that points to a potential issue. This is not a critical error,
but may require attention to get the desired response.
